hints_html: How is the probability density function related to the cumulative distribution function?
hints_latex:
How is the probability density function related to the cumulative
distribution function?
hints_raw: How is the probability density function related to the cumulative distribution function?
question: 5 (a)
sols_html:
The probability density function is the derivative of the cumulative distribution function,

\[\begin{aligned} p_A(t) &= F_A'(t) = \frac{d}{dt} (1-e^{-t}) = 0-(-e^{-t})=e^{-t}.\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
The probability density function is the derivative of the cumulative distribution function,

<math> \begin{align}
p_A(t) &= F_A'(t) = \frac{d}{dt} (1-e^{-t}) = 0-(-e^{-t})=e^{-t}.
\end{align}</math>
statement_html:
In a room two different lightbulbs \(A\) and \(B\) are installed. According to the packaging, lightbulb \(A\) fails before time \(t\) with probability \(F_A(t)=1-e^{-t}\) (\(t\) in months). Lightbulb \(B\) has a probability density function for the failure time given by \(p_B(t)=Ce^{-2t}.\)

What is the probability density function for the failure time of lightbulb \(A\)?
statement_latex:
In a room two different lightbulbs $A$ and $B$ are installed. According
to the packaging, lightbulb $A$ fails before time $t$ with probability
$F_A(t)=1-e^{-t}$ ($t$ in months). Lightbulb $B$ has a probability
density function for the failure time given by $p_B(t)=Ce^{-2t}.$

What is the probability density function for the failure time of
lightbulb $A$?
statement_raw:
In a  room two different lightbulbs <math>A</math> and <math>B</math> are installed. According to the packaging, lightbulb <math>A</math> fails before time <math>t</math> with probability <math>F_A(t)=1-e^{-t}</math> (<math>t</math> in months). Lightbulb <math>B</math> has a probability density function for the failure time given by <math>p_B(t)=Ce^{-2t}.</math>

What is the probability density function for the failure time of lightbulb <math>A</math>?
